Less than a year ago, construction began on the new lane that runs parallel to a section of the existing canal, stretching 72km (44 miles) in length. This new route, designed to accommodate larger vessels and facilitate two-way traffic, saw several container ships from across the globe successfully navigating it during a trial run on Saturday. Helicopters and naval vessels provided a security escort for the ships, as the Sinai Peninsula, which borders the canal, remains a stronghold for Islamic militants responsible for numerous deadly attacks since the overthrow of President Mohammed Morsi in 2013. The original Suez Canal, a vital waterway connecting the Mediterranean and Red Seas, has been in operation for nearly 150 years. Egyptian President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi believes the expansion of this crucial shipping route will not only boost trade but also create job opportunities throughout the country. Currently handling 7% of global maritime trade, the Suez Canal plays a pivotal role in the world economy.
